Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Using Lean LaunchPad to Promote Transfer Students' Persistence in Engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research project focuses on improving the success of transfer students through an innovative transition program that utilizes a Lean LaunchPad model. The Lean LaunchPad presents a practice-oriented paradigm for teaching students about innovation and entrepreneurship. It focuses on the startup experience and the skills necessary to develop successful business ventures. By promoting the development of research, analytical thinking, and problem solving skills in engineering students, the Lean LaunchPad approach provides a relevant platform for academic support and experiential learning. Students learn that failure is a necessary part of learning that allows them to gain valuable research, innovation, and design experiences regardless of whether the business case for an idea is viable or not.

The project focus on the transferability of knowledge into real-world application is expected to increase students' persistence in engineering majors. Howard University and New Mexico State University will each implement a one week immersive experience for 40 incoming transfer students using Lean LaunchPad as the format. The transfer students will work in teams to explore the business model canvas, immersing themselves in core portions of the scientific method in an experiential, inquiry based, learner centered environment. In addition, Howard University will adopt and adapt the proven successful NMSU transfer student recruitment methods.

The broader significance and importance of this project is in the innovative use of Lean LaunchPad to ease the transition for incoming transfer students. Community colleges enroll over half of all Hispanic students and 41% of all African American students. This target population has enormous potential for broadening participation in the engineering workforce. Of equal importance is the fact that this research project will address the lack of evidenced based interventions that support the success of transfer students. The success of this project as evidenced by improved retention and graduation numbers can be replicated across varying institutional types.

This project overlaps with NSF's strategic goals of broadening participation in the engineering workforce. The transfer student population is extremely diverse in multiple ways; gender, race, age being the most obvious. The population is growing and increasingly includes veterans returning from active duty. By targeting transfer students, introducing them to entrepreneurship from an engineering perspective and supporting their transition to a four year institution, this project will evaluate the impact of a Lean LaunchPad based immersive experience on their success in earning undergraduate engineering degrees.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of this grant are to create an inclusive environment for new transfer students, providing a one-week workshop before school starts, so that they enter their fall semester with confidence and an understandinig of resources available to them for success with their academic goals. Students enter the university with a network of friends and faculty who have reached out to them as someone they can depend on when needed.

The outcomes of this grant are threefold: 1. higher retention of transfer students 2. students are exposed to a variety of knowledge areas 3. Faculty professional development in an accelerated experiental teaching/learning  format.  These workshops have introduced students to the Lean LaunchPad (LLP) curriculum which has exposed them to entrepreneurial, business, and team building experiences. Workshop faculty strengthened their mentoring skills with one-on-one and group mentoring during and after the workshop. They gained valuable experience teaching a non-traditional, experiencial class with a challenging curriculum and time frame. These methods we believe have contributed to a high retention of the summer cohorts. The first year retention of the LLP participants is approximately 91% when the non-LLP engineering transfer first year retention is approximately 82%. The second year retention of the LLP participants is approximately the same as the non-LLP engineering transfer second year retention. A very high percentage of students in all three cohorts that have not graduated are still enrolled in engineering (80%).

The New Mexico State University system community colleges were briefed on the objectives for the grant in order to help recruit students into the summer workshop and engineering programs. Currently, formal plans with the community colleges are underway to provide a process for students to transfer into the college of Engineering. The process will include programs like this one, for students to attend during and right before they enter the College of Engineering. An example is our NMSU system wide "Aggie Pathway" designed to accept students who do not meet main campus entrance requirements, and to provide developmental resources and opportunities so they are strong transfer students.   

This grant informed planning and design of the Engineering Learning Community (ELC), an 8,000 square foot space housed in the college of engineering that is used for tutoring, mentoring, and group study. The space has been used for these services for two semesters and will be newly renovated this summer 2018. Due to the success of this grant, this space will offer a similar program for transfer students each year at the beginning of the fall semester. Best practices in higher retention and graduation rates have been recognized and supported by the College and Institution. Through careful, strategic planning, New Mexico State University has committed to providing students with quality degree programs, strong faculty mentoring, opportunities to conduct research, and the chance to develop the skills that make them attractive to employers. The ELC will serve as the centerpiece of the College of Engineering’s efforts to meet these goals. The ELC will address factors that are barriers toward earning a degree. It is a sense of community will make students feel they belong in the profession. It is the ability to connect classroom work with hands-on activities that will give students the self-assurance they need to advance. The results of this grant has shown us that transfer students have the same barriers as first time freshmen, and projest like Lean LaunchPad help validate a student's purpose in pursuing engineering while providing an inclusive environment. In other words, the results of this grant helped inform the planning of the new ELC. The University Administration and Foundation have played a significant role in assisting with fund raising for the ELC based on its mission.
